respondent.name: UNITED STATES, EX REL. WYKENNA WATSON.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next in Case 08-6261, Robertson v. United States, ex rel. Watson. Ms. Frankfurt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. He didn't make that argument, though. I mean, his -- as I recall, his only complaint was that he had been promised that -- that he wouldn't be -- he wouldn't be prosecuted. And that was his only complaint below, wasn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He made the constitutional claim below?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Excuse me. We have plenty of plea agreements jurisprudence that say if the Southern District of New York prosecutes someone and they sign a plea agreement and say, we're not going to prosecute you for further crimes, we read that to mean that the Southern District of New York won't prosecute you for further crimes. We don't read it that no other government agency is bound, who has jurisdiction over that criminal activity, that they are equally bound. So why isn't this case the same? Assuming -- that you're making a broad statement, that this has to be brought in the name of the government. Assuming that's correct, does that mean that -- why does that mean that both the U.S. Attorney's Office and the Attorney General's Office, which appear to be two different entities enforcing two different sets of law, why would both be bound?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. It's not just the Southern District; it's also what, the State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I got you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That did puzzle me. I was wondering if there's -- if there's coordinate jurisdiction. Can the -- can the District prosecute for crimes that the Attorney General can prosecute for?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is this law unique to the District or do other States -- I mean, the problem that they are trying to get a handle on is domestic violence. And the prosecutors are busy prosecuting drug crimes and the rest. So the District's solution is, we will allow the abused person to initiate this criminal contempt. Are there other States that have the same procedure?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I -- I mean, however you describe it in practical terms, are there other places that say, abused person, you can initiate this and you can have your lawyer present it, whether it's on behalf of the State or -- but just the practical of how you go through the motions; are there other States that allow the victim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In criminal cases, because I -- I -- correct me if I am wrong, but my -- my recollection is that orders to show cause for contempt in the civil -- on the civil side occur frequently, and that allows a jail sentence in California I think of 5 days -- and this is civil, because it's coercive. Now, you are talking about something different, I take it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And, of course -- MS. FRANKFURT -- and who can nolle the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the States don't have the same compulsion that the Federal Government has, which arises from the separation of powers. And -- which -- which means that it is the executive that has the right to prosecute, and States are not bound by such a thing. And they can perhaps allow private individuals to prosecute, whereas the only exception we have made from the -- from the chief executive's authority to prosecute is Young, which is a very narrow exception, dealing with the Court's ability to protect itself from contempt of its orders. And here the court had nothing to do with the appointment of this private party, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Am I right that the District has been following this procedure for quite some time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, where a private party initiates, the beneficiary of an order of this kind, initiates a contempt proceeding against a person who violates it, and seeks a punishment for it, not just discontinuance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It doesn't say to me that the plea agreement goes to the question of whether there is sort of an inherent violation of the Constitution by adopting this procedure at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I have trouble figuring out whether the plea agreement has any relevance to the kind of basic argument you are making.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Or just to say the lower court was wrong --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- on that premise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We have another option, once we say they were wrong on that premise, to send it back and let them look at the second question, which is whether or not a private party can bring an action in the name of the sovereign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And if -- if that's true, they have been following an unconstitutional practice for about 25 years; is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And nobody thought about it in all this time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because it is done many, many times, as I understand it, over the years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This wouldn't be allowed under Young. I mean, if Young made anything clear is you couldn't appoint as a prosecutor an interested party. And here is the most the interested party of all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So don't -- don't -- don't say that Young would have allowed it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does -- does the Justice Department concede that the sovereign here is the United States? Does the Justice Department concede --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that there can't be a separate prosecutor from -- from the Assistant United States Attorney and that is the prosecutor for the District of Columbia?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't understand them to be saying that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, we can ask the government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Have -- have we had cases that said that Federal separation of powers principles are binding on territorial governments, for instance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is the District a territory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Could I -- I have this question. This -- again, I'm trying to see the case in the broad -- in the broader sense. Supposing there is a civil lawsuit that's settled and part of the settlement is a consent decree that would enjoin certain conduct, and the defendant then violates the decree and engages in the prohibited conduct. Are you saying that the only person who could prosecute for contempt would be the sovereign?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, no, the question would be whether the lawyer for the -- the party who entered into the settlement could bring a contempt proceeding against the adversary who had violated the settlement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What do you think the best authority from this Court for your basic proposition is? What is your strongest case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You think Gompers is the best case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what is your position and can you advise us -- I know it's not in your case -- if there is a plea bargain in the Southern District of New York, does it -- does bind, do you think, the prosecutor in the Eastern District? What is your view of that proposition? I know it's not part of this case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Long.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, but the argument is that because a private interested party can't bring it, the party is bringing it on behalf of the United States and his plea agreement therefore is with the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I'm not sure I understand your point. Yes, the caption doesn't have to be styled in a particular name --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the prosecuting person --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- the person whose name is listed is acting for someone.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you define what you see as that issue? What's the issue that you think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you mean? Not on their own -- not on their own behalf. I mean, that -- that's a quite different issue. That's the issue that was decided below, whether --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- whether a private interested party can be authorized to bring the suit on behalf of the sovereign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand, but you -- you covered two things. You said whether a private individual can bring it on his own.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or whether a private individual can be appointed to bring it on behalf of the sovereign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I thought it was only -- only the second of these that you say is out of the case. You say the first is out of the case, too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: As representative of the sovereign?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And nobody doubts -- I didn't think it was at issue that the United States, rather than operating through the Assistant U.S. Attorney, can appoint you to handle the prosecution.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And that's what they don't dispute, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, that's -- they don't dispute that? That's the point you were trying to make?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, repeat it for me. I sort of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: On whose behalf? That's the issue that I'm trying to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay. Are you saying that it's out of the case that if we say it's on behalf of the United States, they are not challenging that they can do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's so -- so if we say they can act on behalf of the United States, you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So in other words, if, in fact -- you agree or don't agree, I don't know -- but the government says and they say, the government of the United States has here -- and it can, under the Constitution, delegate to a private person the authority to prosecute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is a big argument against that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The argument is: This would be the one person you can't delegate it to because they are very biased.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that argument, you say, is not in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. So now we have what is in the case, which is the question of whether, leaving that argument out of it, did they hear or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know what you mean by "in the interest of"? On behalf of? Is that what you mean? Are you saying -- you acknowledge here that it is on behalf of the United States but you say it doesn't have to be in the interest of the United States, is that it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know what that means. Are you asserting that this suit has been brought on behalf of the United States by your client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why is that even relevant? Why do you even get to that? Isn't the question what the parties understood the plea agreement to mean?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's highly relevant, I think, because I think you would you like to make the argument, which I would like to hear, is that: Forget the United States. The Constitution permits this woman to bring the case as a private citizen.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, if you are right about that, the plea agreement drops out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because nobody says made a plea agreement with her. Because that is the argument you want to make at some point. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But, well -- well, with respect, even if the Constitution permits this, if the parties understood the plea agreement to mean that this was going to be barred, then why isn't that the end of the matter?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And I suppose the argument could be that the -- that the government has no authority under D.C. law to enter into such an agreement, as well require these two --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Gee, I have really lost you. What is going off in a different direction? Really? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, okay. You're -- you're asserting that this agreement with the United States Attorney cannot cover this case because your client was not acting on behalf of the United States, but rather in her private capacity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's perfectly okay, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, one way you can find it in the Constitution is that we have built a body of law about the obligation of people bringing prosecutions that wouldn't fit within your situation. For -- what are the Brady -- what's the Brady obligation of your client?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What are the Brady obligations of your client?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What -- what are the Brady obligations of your client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So your client has to provide the -- her husband a lawyer? Who has to provide a lawyer in this criminal contempt proceeding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't know if you have answered the Chief's question. He has asked to have a lawyer; is there a Brady obligation? What are the constitutional entitlements --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But can we get to the Brady? That was one of the questions I had, too. Let's say we have the -- we'll call it a private person as prosecuting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does that person have a -- a right to look at all the government files to see if there is any exonerating evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, how does it work? That's what we want to know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But how does it work? Does -- does the -- does the person who is bringing this prosecution have the right to go in and -- and look at the -- all -- all of the files that the police have --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- and that the prosecutor has? That's the only way Brady would work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What do we do about that? Because it's very hard for me to focus on the case -- the issue you want me to decide --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- without thinking about the one you don't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the reasons, as I have categorized this -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what do --- so what do we do? I mean, I think of this as like Aeschylus; you have the Furies gradually giving way to justice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, private --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- vengeance is out and justice is in, and we have 3,000 years of that, and they are all going to be variations of that theme and we could think of 100 arguments. Boasting. Then is this special?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, before I can answer that question, I would like to know whether the government could appoint the private person. After all there is a check -- there is a check against the total Furies, it's the government doing it. Now you say no, the government can't do it, so -- but they can do it on their own. Maybe -- I don't know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How do I get my -- how do I begin to answer these questions bound together in my mind in some partial way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But you want to do that. You see, so there is no control. You are saying we want the private individuals to have the authority to bring criminal contempt; they are on their own; they decide it. The government has nothing to say about this. It's a totally private matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Some problems have no answers. I mean, that doesn't prove anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think that Congress could -- could set up a private organization to expend Federal funds -- we are going to abolish the Department of Education. And we are going to give its function to a private organization that will take care of all those things. No good, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: On -- on behalf of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- on behalf of the executive. You are looking for a section of the Constitution; I suggest Article II, Section 1, the executive power shall be vested in the President.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And just as the executive power includes the power to expend funds appropriated by Congress, so also the executive power except in the -- in the instance of necessity acknowledged by Young, which I think was wrongly decided anyway -- except in that one narrow instance, the -- the power to prosecute belongs to the executive.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now the State of California, trying to save money, say we have a very good idea. We are going to pass one law, abolish all the prosecutors' offices and say wherever there is a victim of crime, that victim will bring the prosecution. Now you really are back to the Furies. Is that constitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, there was, before -- before Aeschylus. Or whatever. But the -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You would say that that is constitutional --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- to have a statute that all criminal prosecutions would be brought by victims, period?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. If there are, then why aren't there the same here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, I don't think that's right. Private prosecutions were common at the time of the framing? You have got to go back a long way before they were common.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not sure why -- how we can avoid it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, this case properly presents the argument that a private party can't bring a criminal prosecution on their -- in their own -- perhaps their own name, they can, but on their own, in their own interest. It always has to be a government interest. That's what the argument is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You are saying the answer to that is, no, they can bring a claim in their own name?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, no. But the last question is the one that they are disputing; it can't be in their own interest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And you are saying it can.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Answer why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You might -- you might -- you might say this. To answer your question that is here, there are a couple of ways of doing this. One way you would say is, well, don't worry about this so much. If the answer is no, you can still bring your private prosecution but you have got to get government permission, because you are doing it in the way of the government. But if the answer to the question is if you can't do either, they you might say, then why wouldn't you say why well, aren't we back to the Eumenides, and the answer is going to be this is say contempt. Contempt is special. I don't know whether either or both of those ways would work. So what would you think, since the government has changed its position, of sending this back so some of these things can be worked out? At least we would have some opinions that would help us.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, unless you think it's a violation of due process for an interested party to be able to criminally prosecute someone at their -- at their discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You want to plea bargain with a -- with an interested party?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Criminal -- criminal contempt prosecution or civil contempt prosecution?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Those are in every state?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, there can be order to show cause, but you are saying that every state allows a private person to have a criminal prosecution for criminal contempt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, a -- a motion is different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then the courts decide -- then the court decides based on the position of the defendant, of the person who is charged with contempt --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- whether or not to proceed. And the court certainly can appoint a prosecutor, and does in many states.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, well, that's a different matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's -- that's -- why isn't it a different matter?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so now you are into the question of what counts as a prosecution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And there again, I am at sea. I don't know what the authority is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that the situation here in D.C.? When the woman comes in, can the judge look it over and say, Ah, you don't have anything here; I'm not going to -- I'm not going to allow you to go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How do you understand -- how does the statute read? As I understand it, it's not up to the judge to decide whether there is enough there to allow her to go forward or to appoint somebody on his own. She is the prosecutor. It's up to her whether there is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A hearing on whether she can prosecute or a hearing on -- on whether he's going to be guilty or not.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But can your private prosecutor, however you want to describe her, could she enter into a plea agreement with the defendant?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, she said you could be subject to you 180 days; I will agree, and you'll plead guilty to 30 days.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or pay $1,000 to your victim, which is me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I accept that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But a specific country -- this is the point Justice Scalia was making -- the rest of the country, it's a state system.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And -- and there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but that's -- that's the question. That's the question that I don't know that we have enough information in the record about. Is this really -- is this prosecution like a state? That's the Solicitor General's position, which is, it's on behalf of the local government, not on the behalf of the Federal government as a sovereign. I think that's what this case speaks to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there somewhere I can look to see what happens? All I can find in the long law is that a violation of the order is a contempt. Fine; no problem. And then the only word about the Petitioner, it says the Petitioner is entitled to relief under this chapter, which contains about 50 different things. And it doesn't say what kind of relief. It doesn't say how you get relief. It doesn't say if you are just asking -- all those things you raised. So how do I find out actually what is in the system.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It doesn't say that. It says the earlier part of this statute which goes on for six pages in an earlier part of this statue, which goes on for six pages, seven pages. It says, a Petitioner has a right to seek relief under this subchapter. Now, that contains civil contempt. It contains how you get protective orders. It contains a lot of things that are absolutely noncontroversial. So

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. General Kagan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Whose state power was she acting on behalf of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Courts don't have the power to incarcerate people. I mean, if you are prosecuting for a criminal offense, you are exercising more than the power of the Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But nobody asserted in Young that the prosecutor appointed by the court was only exercising the power of the court. Surely it was the power of the government that the -- that the prosecutor was exercising. Now, the court was given the power to appoint that prosecutor, but I would think it's extraordinary to say that there's nothing but the court's power in play.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Then why doesn't an agreement by the United States not to prosecute carry the day?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's -- that's absolutely startling. The different U.S. Attorneys all work for your boss, right? They work for the Attorney General. How can one part of the Attorney General agree to something that doesn't bind the other part of the Attorney General?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I take your word for it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Maybe or maybe not, but surely it binds the New Jersey U.S. Attorney. If you -- just think about it. The -- the U.S. Attorney from the Southern District says: Look, you agree to go to jail for 10 years and I will drop these 3 charges. Done. Then the U.S. Attorney for New Jersey can come in and prosecute under those three charges?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, how do you get -- I mean, you are a defendant. You have to go to all more than 50, all the U.S. Attorney's Offices and say, will you agree to this and get everybody to sign off?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It can't do that. If the U.S. attorney in New Jersey has the authority to prosecute this, the U.S. Attorney in New York can't say, oh, and by the way I bind all the other U.S. Attorneys.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But do I understand your position that in this particular case the U.S. Attorney could have entered into a settlement agreement that would have bound the Respondent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You draw a distinction between the D.C. Circuit -- the D.C. and the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But you would agree, I take it, that the attorney for the District of Columbia could have bound Respondent? Somebody could bind Respondent without Respondent even knowing about it, that's what I'm asking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I have to agree with you that to accept this argument that the prosecutor here is an agent just of the court, just of the D.C. court, not an agent of the executive?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I'm not making the argument.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Usually we have questions the other way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know that courts have ever asserted that they themselves have the power to prosecute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not on behalf of the court. On behalf of the government, and that's why Young said you should offer it first to the United States Attorney, and only if he won't bring it, then you can appoint somebody else to bring it. But the -- the prosecutor is not the court. My God. What a terrible situation. The prosecutor's the court, the judge is the court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't it the case that only the U.S. Attorney can prosecute for this crime? Could the D.C. attorney general or whatever the name of it, what, counsel, prosecute for this felony?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Because it's all up to the court; the court's the big prosecutor, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, if there were a finding of innocent, or not guilty, by this prosecutor, could the official prosecutor then prosecute again, or would there be double jeopardy? If you are saying they are somehow separate, does the double jeopardy clause apply?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but that was the same authority.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you don't think this is a Bartkiss-like case, like Bartkiss v. Illinois?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That a State prosecution doesn't bar a later Federal prosecution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is your argument the broad argument that the Chief Justice was talking about, that we have a man who drives in a car from Baltimore to rob a bank in Washington and the U.S. Attorney in Washington gives him a piece of paper which says, I will not prosecute you for this now or in the future, and suddenly the U.S. Attorney in Baltimore prosecutes it. Are you saying that that is barred or not barred? That's the broad argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or are you making a narrow argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I'm just asking you your position on that. Can the -- does this piece of paper from the U.S. Attorney in Washington bar prosecution by the U.S. attorney in Baltimore? Yes or no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It does bar?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, could I ask you could a 1983 or I guess Bivens action be brought against Ms. Watson? The defendant, you know, it turns out he's not guilty and he thinks there was malice. Could he bring a Bivens action against her?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: She's a State actor. She's acting on behalf either of the United States or the District of Columbia. Therefore, she can be sued directly and be personally liable.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, briefly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General. Ms. Frankfurt, you have 7 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you this: The District of Columbia Court of Appeals said we are satisfied that no objectively reasonable person could understand that Mr. Robertson's plea agreement bound Ms. Watson and precluded her contempt proceeding against Mr. Robertson. If we accept that, is there any other issue in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And did you preserve that? If -- if Mr. -- Mr. Robertson had said, I understand this only means that I am not going to be charged with a -- a criminal offense by the United States Attorney's Office for the District of Columbia, and it has no application to this civil contempt proceeding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But that's a separate question. So the first question is: What was agreed to under the plea agreement, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Just so I understand what is before us, you preserve -- you saying -- you are saying you preserve the issue that even if your client fully understood that this plea agreement had no application to a criminal contempt proceeding, he preserved the argument that he could contest the criminal contempt proceeding on the ground that it would be unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No, I understand that. I understand there's the contract issue. But did you -- in the lower court, did you argue even if he gave that up, under the plea agreement, the criminal contempt proceeding still could not be brought?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Even if he didn't get that -- a bar to that under the plea agreement, the contempt proceeding would still be barred for some other reason? Did you make that argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You did raise, undoubtedly you say, the point that the only way in which she could be the prosecutor was as an agent of the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that it was unconstitutional for her to -- to represent herself.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
